resume_text:
Part 1: A Voyage to Lilliput ‚Äî 50+ MCQs  
1. What is the approximate height of a Lilliputian?  
A) 12 inches  
B) 6 inches  
C) 2 feet  
D) 1 foot  
Answer: B  
2. What causes Gulliver to wash ashore on Lilliput?  
A) A storm at sea  
B) A shipwreck  
C) A pirate attack  
D) A mutiny  
Answer: B  
3. How do the Lilliputians initially react to Gulliver?  
A) They attack him immediately  
B) They bind him with ropes and chains  
C) They invite him to their palace  
D) They run away in fear  
Answer: B  
4. How does Gulliver communicate with the Li lliputians?  
A) Through signs and gestures  
B) He speaks their language fluently  
C) Through a translator  
D) He writes notes  
Answer: A  
5. Which political groups are in conflict in Lilliput?  
A) Conservatives and Liberals  
B) The Left -Heels and Right -Heels  
C) The H igh-Heels and Low -Heels  
D) The Reds and Blues  
Answer: C  
6. What is the reason for the conflict between the High -Heels and Low -Heels?  
A) Religious differences  
B) Disagreement on the proper way to crack eggs  
C) Land ownership disputes  
D) Economic policies  
Answe r: B 
7. Who is the ruler of Lilliput?  
A) The Emperor  
B) The Prime Minister  
C) The High Priest  
D) The General  
Answer: A  
8. How does Gulliver help the Lilliputians in their war against Blefuscu?  
A) He builds weapons for them  
B) He captures their ships and soldiers  
C) He teaches them strategy  
D) He fights alongside them  
Answer: B  
9. What absurd punishment does Lilliput impose on those who break the law?  
A) Amputation of a limb  
B) Blinding  
C) Cutting off the heel  
D) Execution  
Answer: C  
10. What satire is reflected by the Li lliputian emperor‚Äôs fear of Gulliver?  
A) Fear of foreign invasion  
B) Distrust of the powerful by the weak  
C) Distrust of knowledge  
D) Religious intolerance  
Answer: B  
11. Why do the Lilliputians consider Gulliver dangerous?  
A) Because of his large size and pote ntial to overthrow the emperor  
B) Because he spreads disease  
C) Because he refuses to obey their laws  
D) Because he steals from them  
Answer: A  
12. What does Gulliver‚Äôs treatment in Lilliput satirize?  
A) Treatment of prisoners of war  
B) Colonial domination  
C) T he arbitrary exercise of power  
D) Religious persecution  
Answer: C  
13. What is the ‚ÄúHigh -Heels‚Äù vs ‚ÄúLow -Heels‚Äù conflict a metaphor for?  
A) Political party rivalries in England  
B) International diplomacy  
C) Economic class struggle  
D) Scientific disagreements  
Answer: A  
14. How does Gulliver behave towards the Lilliputians?  
A) With cruelty  
B) With kindness and protection  
C) With indifference  
D) With arrogance  
Answer: B  
15. How does Gulliver demonstrate his loyalty to Lilliput?  
A) He agrees to spy on Blefuscu  
B) He helps bu ild Lilliputian navy  
C) He captures the Blefuscudian fleet  
D) He helps the emperor escape  
Answer: C  
16. What does Gulliver‚Äôs size symbolize in the political satire?  
A) Military strength  
B) The disproportion between power and authority  
C) The innocence of man  
D) Economic wealth  
Answer: B  
17. How does Gulliver escape from Lilliput?  
A) He is set free by the emperor  
B) He swims away  
C) He steals a boat and sails off  
D) The Blefuscudians rescue him  
Answer: C  
18. What role does flattery play in Lilliputian politics?  
A) It is  essential for survival and advancement  
B) It is discouraged  
C) It is punishable by law  
D) It has no role  
Answer: A  
19. Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of the Lilliputians?  
A) Petty  
B) Proud  
C) Generous  
D) Politically divisive  
Answer: C  
20. How does  Swift use the Lilliputians‚Äô small size to mock human nature?  
A) By showing their huge egos despite tiny stature  
B) By showing their physical strength  
C) By showing their wisdom  
D) By showing their bravery  
Answer: A  
21. What is the significance of Gulliver‚Äôs r efusal to help Lilliput attack Blefuscu?  
A) It shows his loyalty to England  
B) It causes political trouble for Gulliver  
C) It demonstrates moral neutrality  
D) It saves Blefuscu  
Answer: B  
22. Why does the emperor of Lilliput order Gulliver‚Äôs punishment?  
A) For failing to obey orders  
B) For political manipulation and jealousy  
C) For stealing treasure  
D) For attacking citizens  
Answer: B  
23. What is the main mode of transport for Gulliver in Lilliput?  
A) Horseback  
B) On foot  
C) On a floating boat  
D) Carriage  
Answer: B  
24. How are women portrayed in Lilliput?  
A) Powerful and respected  
B) Mostly ignored or minor characters  
C) Rulers of the empire  
D) Warriors  
Answer: B  
25. What role does Gulliver‚Äôs honesty play in the story?  
A) It makes him unpopular  
B) It helps him gain trust ini tially  
C) It causes his downfall  
D) It is irrelevant  
Answer: B  
26. What kind of government does Lilliput have?  
A) Democracy  
B) Monarchy with advisors and ministers  
C) Republic  
D) Anarchy  
Answer: B  
27. How does Gulliver‚Äôs presence affect the Lilliputian society?  
A) Causes peace  
B) Disrupts their political balance  
C) Has no effect  
D) Leads to economic growth  
Answer: B  
28. How do the Lilliputians view Gulliver‚Äôs strength?  
A) With awe and fear  
B) With contempt  
C) With jealousy  
D) With hatred  
Answer: A  
29. What satirical point does the method of binding Gulliver make?  
A) People‚Äôs overreliance on brute force  
B) The futility of attempting to control something much bigger  
C) Cleverness in war  
D) Religious rituals  
Answer: B  
30. What does the conflict between Lillipu t and Blefuscu represent?  
A) English -French rivalry  
B) Rival kingdoms in history  
C) Religious conflicts  
D) Trade disputes  
Answer: A  
31. What is the significance of Gulliver‚Äôs captivity?  
A) It shows how small societies treat foreigners  
B) It symbolizes man‚Äôs do mination over nature  
C) It critiques colonialism  
D) It demonstrates justice  
Answer: C  
32. How does Swift use exaggeration in the depiction of Lilliput?  
A) To entertain only  
B) To highlight the absurdity of human behavior  
C) To confuse readers  
D) To praise huma n achievement  
Answer: B  
33. What is the significance of Gulliver‚Äôs escape in the narrative?  
A) Shows his survival instincts  
B) Symbolizes escape from political oppression  
C) Leads to new adventures  
D) All of the above  
Answer: D  
34. What is the attitude of Lilliput ians toward Gulliver‚Äôs intelligence?  
A) They respect it  
B) They are indifferent  
C) They fear and mistrust it  
D) They ignore it  
Answer: C  
35. How does the emperor treat Gulliver after his help in the war?  
A) Honors him  
B) Imprisons him  
C) Distrusts and punishes  him 
D) Sends him home  
Answer: C  
36. What is the lesson Gulliver learns from Lilliput?  
A) Power is everything  
B) Pride and pettiness are common even in small matters  
C) War is noble  
D) Loyalty is overrated  
Answer: B  
37. What role does satire play in Lilliput‚Äôs dep iction?  
A) To entertain only  
B) To criticize contemporary British politics  
C) To praise monarchy  
D) To highlight nature‚Äôs beauty  
Answer: B  
38. What is the main reason for Gulliver‚Äôs release?  
A) He promises loyalty  
B) He steals a ship  
C) The emperor pardons him  
D) He escapes by himself  
Answer: D  
39. What physical feature is a symbol of power in Lilliput?  
A) Height  
B) Footwear heel height  
C) Hair length  
D) Clothing color  
Answer: B  
40. What does Gulliver‚Äôs relationship with the Lilliputians teach about diplomacy?  
A) Brute  force is always best  
B) Understanding and cooperation are important but complicated  
C) Foreigners can never be trusted  
D) Diplomacy is useless  
Answer: B  
41. How does the Lilliputian court resemble the British court?  
A) In political intrigue and factions  
B) In  architecture  
C) In language  
D) In food  
Answer: A  
42. What does Gulliver‚Äôs size give him in Lilliput?  
A) Wealth  
B) Power and influence  
C) Fear and suspicion  
D) Nothing special  
Answer: C  
43. What is Gulliver‚Äôs initial attitude toward the Lilliputians?  
A) Hostile  
B) Curious and kind  
C) Indifferent  
D) Arrogant  
Answer: B  
44. What is the nature of laws in Lilliput?  
A) Fair and just  
B) Arbitrary and petty  
C) Nonexistent  
D) Strictly enforced  
Answer: B  
45. How is Gulliver described physically compared to Lilliputians?  
A) Like a gi ant god  
B) Like a normal man  
C) Like a monster  
D) Like a king  
Answer: A  
46. What lesson does Swift convey about human nature through Lilliput?  
A) Humans are noble and great  
B) Humans are petty and vain  
C) Humans are courageous  
D) Humans are simple  
Answer: B  
47. What does Gulliver learn about loyalty in Lilliput?  
A) It is valued highly  
B) It is fragile and influenced by politics  
C) It is absolute  
D) It is irrelevant  
Answer: B  
48. How does Gulliver help Lilliput in the war?  
A) By attacking Blefuscu personally  
B) By usi ng his size to capture Blefuscudian ships  
C) By negotiating peace  
D) By providing weapons  
Answer: B  
49. What ultimately causes Gulliver to leave Lilliput?  
A) Desire for adventure  
B) Political suspicion and falling out with the emperor  
C) Illness  
D) A call from  his family  
Answer: B  
50. How does the Lilliput story criticize British politics?  
A) Through literal political events  
B) Through allegory of trivial conflicts over heels and eggs  
C) Through scientific discourse  
D) Through battle descriptions  
Answer: B  
Part 2: A Voyage to Brobdingnag ‚Äî 50+ MCQs  
1. How tall are the Brobdingnagians compared to Gulliver?  
A) Same size  
B) Twice his height  
C) About 60 feet tall  
D) Very small  
Answer: C  
2. What happens to Gulliver when he arrives in Brobdingnag?  
A) He becomes a prisoner  
B) He  is seen as a pet and curiosity  
C) He is made a king  
D) He is ignored  
Answer: B  
3. Who is the ruler of Brobdingnag?  
A) An emperor  
B) A queen  
C) A king  
D) A president  
Answer: C  
4. How does the King of Brobdingnag view Gulliver?  
A) As a nobleman  
B) As a curiosity and sometimes as a child  
C) As a threat  
D) As a servant  
Answer: B  
5. What is the King‚Äôs opinion on European governments?  
A) He admires them  
B) He finds them corrupt and flawed  
C) He is indifferent  
D) He wants to copy them  
Answer: B  
6. How does the King describe European wars?  
A) Glorious and necessary  
B) Barbaric and ridiculous  
C) Inevitable  
D) Clever and strategic  
Answer: B  
7. What does the King criticize most about European politics?  
A) Its efficiency  
B) Its morality and justice  
C) Its e conomic policies  
D) Its culture  
Answer: B  
8. What is Gulliver‚Äôs size relative to Brobdingnagians?  
A) Average human size  
B) Tiny  
C) Giant  
D) Invisible  
Answer: B  
9. How does Gulliver feel about being small in Brobdingnag?  
A) Proud  
B) Helpless and vulnerable  
C) Ang ry 
D) Happy  
Answer: B  
10. What kind of satire is prominent in Part 2?  
A) Satire of science  
B) Satire of human nature and European society  
C) Satire of religion  
D) Satire of language  
Answer: B  
11. What does the King do when Gulliver describes European political ins titutions?  
A) He praises them  
B) He is shocked and critical  
C) He ignores them  
D) He laughs  
Answer: B  
12. How does the King react to descriptions of the British government?  
A) He finds it fair and just  
B) He considers it corrupt and unjust  
C) He thinks it is t oo strict  
D) He wants to adopt it  
Answer: B  
13. What does the King think about lawyers and politicians?  
A) They are honorable  
B) They are mostly corrupt and self -serving  
C) They are heroes  
D) They are clever  
Answer: B  
14. How does Gulliver entertain himself in Bro bdingnag?  
A) Exploring the countryside  
B) Playing with the children and telling stories  
C) Fighting battles  
D) Studying science  
Answer: B  
15. What is Gulliver‚Äôs main concern living among giants?  
A) Finding food  
B) Avoiding being crushed or eaten  
C) Becoming ki ng 
D) Learning the language  
Answer: B  
16. How are women portrayed in Brobdingnag?  
A) As powerful and respected  
B) As cruel  
C) As minor characters  
D) As warriors  
Answer: A  
17. What does the King give Gulliver?  
A) Wealth and land  
B) Protection and a small house  
C) A  place in court  
D) A ship  
Answer: B  
18. What lesson does Gulliver learn from the King?  
A) Wisdom and morality are important in ruling  
B) Power is everything  
C) War is glorious  
D) Science is supreme  
Answer: A  
19. How does Gulliver describe the landscape of Brobding nag?  
A) Small and cramped  
B) Vast and beautiful  
C) Ugly and dangerous  
D) Desert -like 
Answer: B  
20. What does Gulliver notice about the Brobdingnagians‚Äô behavior?  
A) They are violent  
B) They are kind, rational, and honest  
C) They are greedy  
D) They are deceitfu l 
Answer: B  
21. How does the King treat Gulliver?  
A) As a slave  
B) With kindness and curiosity  
C) As a servant  
D) With indifference  
Answer: B  
22. How does Gulliver‚Äôs perspective on his own country change?  
A) He feels proud  
B) He becomes critical and ashamed  
C) He feels indifferent  
D) He wants to conquer Brobdingnag  
Answer: B  
23. How does Gulliver escape from Brobdingnag?  
A) He is sent away by the King  
B) He falls from a giant eagle‚Äôs nest  
C) He steals a ship  
D) He is rescued by a passing vessel  
Answer: B  
24. What theme doe s Gulliver‚Äôs escape represent?  
A) Freedom and survival  
B) Defeat  
C) Betrayal  
D) Honor  
Answer: A  
25. How does the King react to Gulliver‚Äôs stories about England?  
A) With disbelief  
B) With admiration  
C) With anger  
D) With humor  
Answer: A  
26. What does Brobdingnag‚Äôs size metaphorically represent?  
A) The moral and intellectual ‚Äòlargeness‚Äô in contrast to European pettiness  
B) Physical strength  
C) Wealth  
D) Power  
Answer: A  
27. What kind of government does Brobdingnag have?  
A) Monarchy with wise and just rule  
B) Democracy  
C) Anarchy  
D) Tyranny  
Answer: A  
28. How does Gulliver‚Äôs size affect his ability to interact in Brobdingnag?  
A) He is respected as equal  
B) He is fragile and vulnerable  
C) He is ignored  
D) He is feared  
Answer: B  
29. What does the King do when Gulliver describes the Br itish navy?  
A) He is impressed  
B) He criticizes it as brutal and barbaric  
C) He wants to build a navy  
D) He laughs  
Answer: B  
30. What does Gulliver compare the Brobdingnagians to?  
A) Giants of mythology  
B) Gods  
C) Simple peasants  
D) Wise rulers  
Answer: D  
31. What is the King‚Äôs view on human nature?  
A) Humans are basically good  
B) Humans are flawed and corrupt  
C) Humans are divine  
D) Humans are superior  
Answer: B  
32. What is the significance of the King‚Äôs criticism of Europe?  
A) To promote imperialism  
B) To satirize Eur opean arrogance and moral failings  
C) To show the greatness of Europe  
D) To emphasize war  
Answer: B  
33. How is Gulliver treated by the Brobdingnagians‚Äô servants?  
A) With kindness  
B) With cruelty  
C) With curiosity and care  
D) With indifference  
Answer: C  
34. What does Gulliver‚Äôs vulnerability highlight?  
A) The fragility of human pride  
B) The power of nature  
C) The importance of strength  
D) The dangers of war  
Answer: A  
35. How does Gulliver describe the Brobdingnagians‚Äô speech?  
A) Loud and harsh  
B) Slow and deliber ate 
C) Musical and pleasant  
D) Confusing  
Answer: B  
36. What is one of the King‚Äôs greatest concerns?  
A) Maintaining peace and justice  
B) Conquering new lands  
C) Increasing wealth  
D) Building monuments  
Answer: A  
37. How does Gulliver feel about the King‚Äôs judgments?  
A) Offended  
B) Humbled and thoughtful  
C) Proud  
D) Angry  
Answer: B  
38. What does Gulliver say about the food in Brobdingnag?  
A) It is enormous and hard to eat  
B) It is delicious and plentiful  
C) It is scarce  
D) It is strange and inedible  
Answer: A  
39. How does the  King respond to Gulliver‚Äôs description of English politics?  
A) He praises the system  
B) He condemns it as corrupt and unjust  
C) He ignores it  
D) He mocks Gulliver  
Answer: B  
40. How does Gulliver‚Äôs relationship with the King influence the story?  
A) It creates conflict  
B) It serves as a vehicle for satire on European politics  
C) It is irrelevant  
D) It shows Gulliver‚Äôs weakness  
Answer: B  
41. What does Gulliver find frightening in Brobdingnag?  
A) The large size of everything around him  
B) The people‚Äôs cruelty  
C) The h arsh climate  
D) The animals  
Answer: A  
42. How do the Brobdingnagians view European inventions?  
A) With admiration  
B) With suspicion and skepticism  
C) With envy  
D) With ignorance  
Answer: B  
43. What does Gulliver say about Brobdingnagian justice?  
A) It is harsh  
B) It is fair and rational  
C) It is corrupt  
D) It is non -existent  
Answer: B  
44. What is a significant theme in Part 2?  
A) The folly of human pride and the value of humility  
B) The power of science  
C) The glory of war  
D) The importance of wealth  
Answer: A  
45. How does the King respond to Gulliver‚Äôs talk of England‚Äôs military?  
A) He is proud  
B) He is critical and calls it barbaric  
C) He wants to copy it  
D) He is indifferent  
Answer: B  
46. What does Gulliver‚Äôs experience in Brobdingnag symbolize?  
A) The smallness of h uman concerns in the grand scheme of things  
B) Human superiority  
C) Political power  
D) Technological progress  
Answer: A  
47. How does the King feel about the concept of monarchy in Europe?  
A) He supports it  
B) He is skeptical and critical  
C) He wants to adopt i t 
D) He is indifferent  
Answer: B  
48. What does Gulliver do when he fears for his safety?  
A) He hides  
B) He asks for protection from the King  
C) He escapes  
D) He fights back  
Answer: B  
49. How does Gulliver describe Brobdingnagian architecture?  
A) Gigantic and magni ficent  
B) Small and simple  
C) Ugly  
D) Similar to England‚Äôs  
Answer: A  
50. What is Swift criticizing through the King‚Äôs opinions?  
A) European imperialism and moral corruption  
B) The monarchy  
C) The navy  
D) The church  
Answer: A  
Absolutely! Here are 50+ MCQs for P art 3: A Voyage to Laputa, Balnibarbi, Luggnagg, 
Glubbdubdrib, and Japan , followed by 50+ MCQs for Part 4: A Voyage to the Country of 
the Houyhnhnms  with answers.  
 
Part 3: A Voyage to Laputa, Balnibarbi, 
Luggnagg, Glubbd ubdrib, and Japan ‚Äî 50+ 
MCQs  
1. What is unique about the island of Laputa?  
A) It is underwater  
B) It floats in the air  
C) It is invisible  
D) It is underground  
Answer: B  
2. What are the inhabitants of Laputa obsessed with?  
A) War and politics  
B) Mathematics, musi c, and abstract science  
C) Farming and hunting  
D) Trade and commerce  
Answer: B  
3. How does Gulliver describe the Laputans‚Äô focus?  
A) Practical and useful  
B) Absorbed in useless theoretical knowledge  
C) Balanced  
D) Ruthless  
Answer: B  
4. What is the main problem w ith the floating island?  
A) It causes storms  
B) It blocks sunlight from the land below  
C) It sinks occasionally  
D) It is overcrowded  
Answer: B  
5. What is Balnibarbi known for?  
A) Its wealth  
B) Its poverty and mismanagement due to impractical scientific experi ments  
C) Its military strength  
D) Its beautiful landscapes  
Answer: B  
6. What is the Academy of Lagado?  
A) A military academy  
B) A scientific institution where impractical experiments are conducted  
C) A university of arts  
D) A trading company  
Answer: B  
7. How doe s Gulliver view the experiments at the Academy?  
A) Impressed  
B) Critical and skeptical  
C) Interested  
D) Amused  
Answer: B  
8. What kind of experiments are performed at the Academy?  
A) Useful inventions  
B) Ridiculous and impractical attempts like extracting sunbeams from cucumbers  
C) Medical research  
D) Agricultural improvements  
Answer: B  
9. Who are the Struldbrugs?  
A) People who live forever but age continuously  
B) Wizards  
C) Warriors  
D) Merchants  
Answer: A  
10. What curse do the Struldbrugs suffer from?  
A) Eternal youth but no wisdom  
B) Immortality without eternal youth, causing endless old age and misery  
C) Blindness  
D) Poverty  
Answer: B  
11. What lesson does the story of the Struldbrugs convey?  
A) Immortality is de sirable  
B) Eternal life without youth is a curse  
C) Death is evil  
D) Youth is unimportant  
Answer: B  
12. What happens on the island of Glubbdubdrib?  
A) Gulliver meets magicians who allow him to speak with the dead  
B) Gulliver is imprisoned  
C) Gulliver fights ba ttles 
D) Gulliver studies mathematics  
Answer: A  
13. What does Gulliver learn from the conversations with the dead?  
A) Modern history is inaccurate and biased  
B) The past was perfect  
C) The dead are forgetful  
D) Magic is real  
Answer: A  
14. What does the Laputan obs ession with music and mathematics satirize?  
A) The uselessness of abstract knowledge disconnected from practical life  
B) The greatness of science  
C) The power of education  
D) The importance of art  
Answer: A  
15. What is Gulliver‚Äôs impression of the political le aders in Laputa?  
A) Wise and competent  
B) Distracted and impractical  
C) Cruel  
D) Strong  
Answer: B  
16. How do the Laputans use their floating island militarily?  
A) They drop stones on enemies  
B) They threaten to block sunlight or crush rebellious lands below  
C) They use it as a trading post  
D) They do not use it militarily  
Answer: B  
17. What does Gulliver think of the science in Balnibarbi?  
A) Revolutionary  
B) Wasteful and misguided  
C) Promising  
D) Traditional  
Answer: B  
18. What type of government rules Balnibarbi?  
A) D emocracy  
B) Ruled by the Laputans from above  
C) Anarchy  
D) Monarchy  
Answer: B  
19. How does Gulliver describe the people of Balnibarbi?  
A) Industrious  
B) Poor and suffering due to failed experiments  
C) Wealthy  
D) Peaceful  
Answer: B  
20. What kind of inventions are b eing developed in Lagado?  
A) Practical machines  
B) Silly and useless devices  
C) Advanced weapons  
D) Agricultural tools  
Answer: B  
21. What does Gulliver do in Luggnagg?  
A) Meets immortal Struldbrugs  
B) Participates in a battle  
C) Joins the court  
D) Begins farmi ng 
Answer: A  
22. What is Gulliver‚Äôs general attitude towards the Laputan elite?  
A) Respectful  
B) Critical  
C) Indifferent  
D) Fearful  
Answer: B  
23. What does Gulliver learn about history from Glubbdubdrib?  
A) History is mostly myth  
B) Historical records are often fa lsified or biased  
C) History is perfect  
D) History is irrelevant  
Answer: B  
24. What is the symbolism of Laputa‚Äôs floating?  
A) The detachment of intellectuals from real -world problems  
B) Human progress  
C) Power  
D) Wealth  
Answer: A  
25. How does Gulliver describe the  daily life of Laputans?  
A) Busy and productive  
B) Absorbed in trivial theories and distractions  
C) Military -focused  
D) Religious  
Answer: B  
26. What does Gulliver find humorous about the Laputans?  
A) Their seriousness  
B) Their obsession with music that causes pain 
C) Their kindness  
D) Their bravery  
Answer: B  
27. How do the Laputans communicate?  
A) Verbally
